raw.author: Dante Alighieri
contexts: Dante is the largest instance of the first possibility, and Shakespeare, the overwhelming example of the second.

Dante’s Divine Comedy, according to Stefan George, was “the book and school of the ages,” though that was more true for poets than for anyone else and is properly assigned to Shakespeare’s plays, as will be shown throughout this book.
Dante, Milton, and Wordsworth repeat Pindar’s key metaphor of racing to win the palm, which is a secular immortality strangely at odds with any pious idealism.
while Dante rejoices in the eternal torments he visits upon his very personal enemies.

Even such prophets as Dante and Milton compromised themselves as Blake would or could not, insofar as pragmatic cultural aspirations may be said to have tempted the poets of the Divine Comedy and Paradise Lost.

Catholic distinctions between divine immortality and human fame, firmly founded upon a dogmatic theology, remained fairly precise until the advent of Dante, who regarded himself as a prophet and so implicitly gave his Divine Comedy the status of a new Scripture.
Shakespeare and Dante are the center of the Canon because they excel all other Western writers in cognitive acuity, linguistic energy, and power of invention.
Dante has been the poets’ poet, even as Shakespeare has been the peoples’ poet;
For me, the radical cases of what looks like a fuller autonomy are Dante and, even more, Shakespeare.
What Is Art? discards not only Shakespeare but Dante, Beethoven, and Raphael.
be it in Homer, Dante, or Tolstoy.
But it is as easy to reduce Shakespeare to his context, whatever context, as to reduce Dante to the Florence and Italy of his day.
Universality is the authentic aspect of only a handful of Western writers: Shakespeare, Dante, Cervantes, perhaps Tolstoy.
Centering the Canon for other poets has been the unique role of Dante.
Dante, the second center as it were, is not under similar onslaught
Dante is the most aggressive and polemical of the major Western writers, dwarfing even Milton in this regard.
Beatrice is the signature of Dante’s originality, and her triumphant placement well within the Christian machinery of salvation is her poet’s most audacious act
the Comedy
Like his direct precursors—Dante and Boccaccio—his great originality emerges most strongly in both his characters and his own voice, his mastery of tone and figuration.
Like Dante, Milton wanted to write the divine poem or, pragmatically, a third Testament.
as you can of Shakespeare and Dante

E. R. Curtius’s Goethe is the perfecter and final representative of the literary culture that goes from Homer through Virgil to Dante and that achieved later sublimity in Shakespeare, Cervantes, Milton, and Racine.
Goethe was following Dante, but that could hardly be taken now for a defense.
the final choruses parody Dante’s Paradiso with a subtly savage gusto.
Goethe is indeed the last great writer of the era that Dante inaugurated.
Instead, he loots and parodies Dante’s Paradiso, presenting all readers since with an ultimate problem in perspectivizing.
Petrarch was haunted by Dante, even as Wordsworth, in his major phase, could never evade Milton.
That is George Eliot’s version of Dante’s paradise, expressed as an idealized secular pilgrimage, and this is the vision that Lydgate and Diver fail.

If the question pertains to the beliefs in themselves, the answer would be positive in terms of the past, when there were so many Tolstoyans, but not now, when he must be read in the company of Homer, the Yah wist, Dante, and Shakespeare, as perhaps the only writer since the Renaissance who can challenge them.

Yet What Is Art? (1896)—his fierce denunciation of Greek tragedy, Dante, Michelangelo, Shakespeare, and Beethoven—is contravened by the astonishing Hadji Murad, the short novel he wrote between 1896 and 1904 but left unpublished when he died.
But Hadji Murad is neither the Ulysses of Dante
Not even Wordsworth or Milton, not even Dante could match Tolstoy as a great solipsist.
As with Milton or Dante or Dickinson or Tolstoy, so it is with Ibsen: we have lost sight of his originality because we are contained by that individuality; we have been partly formed by Ibsen.
I know of no other instances in literature, Dante included, in which we are placed so persuasively in an equivocal cosmos,
“I should hesitate between Dante and Shakespeare, but not for long. The Englishman is richer and would get my vote.”
akin to the processes that established Dante as the Catholic author despite his private gnosis of Beatrice
There is a great love for them in Borges, as there is also a passion for Dante, Cervantes, Whitman, Kafka, and others; but there is a great ambivalence as well.
Beckett, like Joyce, presupposes a reader who knows Dante and Shakespeare, Flaubert and Yeats,
Trotsky urged his fellow Marxists to read Dante, but he would find no welcome in our current universities.
In the same way, the crucial early writer in the history of the entire Western literary Canon is not one of the greatest poets—Homer, Dante, Chaucer, and Shakespeare—but Virgil
Virgil, the great link between Hellenistic poetry (Callimachus) and the European epic tradition (Dante, Tasso, Spenser, Milton).

In 1879 the fifty-one-year-old author of War and Peaceand Anna Kareninacame to believe that he had accomplished nothing and that his life was meaningless.

contexts: As the chapter on Freud in this book demonstrates, I favor a Shakespearean reading of Freud, and not a Freudian reading of Shakespeare or of any other writer.
all of Freud that matters most is there in Shakespeare already, with a persuasive critique of Freud besides. The Freudian map of the mind is Shakespeare’s; Freud seems only to have prosified it.
From the Yah wist and Homer to Freud, Kafka, and Beckett is a journey of nearly three millennia.
Strength alone can open it up, the strength of a Freud or a Kafka, persistent in their cognitive negations.
His wisdom transmutes endlessly in all our sages, from Goethe to Freud, even though Shakespeare declined to step forward as a sage.
Sigmund Freud, the master of all who know, went to his death insisting that Moses was an Egyptian and that Oxford wrote Shakespeare.
For Freud, as for Goethe, the works of Shakespeare were the secular center of culture, the hope for a rational glory in mankind still to come.

As a spectacle, it has the force of an image reversing all natural expectations and was famously misread by Sigmund Freud in his “Theme of the Three Caskets” (1913): “Enter Lear with Cordelia dead in his arms.” Cordelia is Death.
The image of Rachel or Beatrice contemplating herself in the mirror tends to summon up Freud’s unfortunate moment when he compared the narcissism of women to that of cats.
Milton and Freud (who greatly esteemed Milton) have in common their mutual debt to Shakespeare and their equally mutual evasion of the debt.
as we more naturally expect to find in the skeptical Montaigne and in Freud, for whom religion was an illusion.
Faust inhabits the domain of Freud’s drives, Eros and Thanatos
Emerson is a wisdom writer, like Nietzsche, Kierkegaard, Freud, and his precursor, Montaigne.
Freud might not have been happy with that formulation
an equivalent to what Freud called in a great figuration “the work of mourning.”
an act of negation as dialectical and profound as any essayed by Nietzsche or Freud.
so that they entered massively into the realm of what Freud called “reality testing,” though without the final Freudian wisdom of making friends with the necessity of dying.
They are closer to the later Freudian mythology of the drives, Eros and Thanatos, and since we possess the drives, we are partly trollish in our nature.
Shakespeare is the inventor of psychoanalysis; Freud, its codifier.
Freud tells us that a healthy Hamlet would murder Claudius, and since Hamlet evades the act, he must be a hysteric.
Freud, as Wittgenstein warned, is a powerful mythologist, the great mythmaker of our time, fit rival to Proust, Joyce, and Kafka as the canonical center of modern literature.
I am baffled by Freud’s judgment that “The paternal relationship . . . is not turned to further account in the drama.”
Few moments even in Proust, Joyce, and Kafka are more memorable than the Freudian wisdom that bids us “renounce love, choose death and make friends with the necessity of dying.”
He had remarked long before that the childlessness of Macbeth and Lady Macbeth was a key to the tragedy’s meaning.
In the 1916 essay, he centers on Lady Macbeth as a character “wrecked by success” and by subsequent remorse
Freud is therefore pragmatically right to assert that Macbeth is a play “about childlessness,”
and he impressively concedes that he cannot give a total interpretation of the play, a concession that would have been equally relevant in his accounts of Hamlet and King Lear,
Freud was anxious about Shakespeare because he had learned anxiety from him, as he had learned ambivalence and narcissism and schism in the self.
Proust, like Freud, can be said to join both Shakespeare and the Hawthorne of The Scarlet Letter in confirming the canonicity of sexual jealousy.
In 1922, the year of Proust’s death (he was just fifty-one), Freud published a powerful, brief essay on sexual jealousy, “Certain Neurotic Mechanisms in Jealousy, Paranoia, and Homosexuality.”
Search is wisdom literature, even as Montaigne, Dr. Johnson, Emerson, and Freud are finally authors who touch a border between meditation and contemplation.

He shares this unbelief with Freud, Woolf, Joyce, Beckett, Proust, Borges, Pessoa, and Neruda—the other canonical figures I have selected from our age—but no one would find in that octet anything like Kafka’s spiritual preoccupations, not even in Beckett, who was affected by Kafka.
He did not accept the Freudian reduction that religious impulses merely betrayed a yearning for the father.
A dread of what Freud called the family romance and of what might be termed the family romance of literature confines Borges to repetition,
as Freud also was, after him.
Freud notes that anxiety is a reaction to the danger of object loss, and Hamm fears the loss of Clov.
I like Freud’s observation that anxiety is only a perception, but a perception of the possibility of anxiety.

raw.author: Samuel Johnson
contexts: Dr. Samuel Johnson, shrewdest of all literary critics, concluded rightly that devotional poetry was impossible

The canonical praise of this magnificence was inaugurated by Samuel Johnson’s preface to the Shakespeare of 1765, and is both revelatory and misleading: “Shakespeare is above all writers, at least above all modern writers, the poet of nature, the poet that holds up to his readers a faithful mirrour of manners and of life.”
The phrase I have quoted is from The Rambler 93

Jane Austen’s earlier heroines, of whom Elizabeth Bennet is the exemplar, manifested the Protestant will as direct descendants of Samuel Richardson’s Clarissa Harlowe, with Dr. Samuel Johnson hovering nearby as moral authority.

Dr. Johnson, in The Rambler 29, on “The folly of anticipating misfortunes,” warned against anxious expectations of any kind, whether fearful or hopeful: because the objects both of fear and hope are yet uncertain, so we ought not to trust the representations of one more than the other, because they are both equally fallacious; as hope enlarges happiness, fear aggravates calamity.
Sometimes I try to visualize Dr. Johnson or George Eliot confronting MTV Rap
Samuel Johnson Works

Dr. Johnson famously could not endure Cordelia’s death: “I was many years ago so shocked by Cordelia’s death, that I know not whether I ever endured to read again the last scenes of the play till I undertook to revise them as an editor.”
Johnson on Milton anticipates Hazlitt
Beckett oddly resembles Dr. Johnson in his attitudes toward mortality
What Johnson and Woolf after him called the Common Reader still exists and possibly goes on welcoming suggestions of what might be read.
commentaries: The author references Johnson's critical judgment on the impossibility of devotional poetry.
The author cites Samuel Johnson's preface to Shakespeare as initiating the canonical praise of Shakespeare's representation of nature.
The author references Johnson's periodical essay 'The Rambler' as the source for the phrase 'the treachery of the human heart.'
The author references Dr. Samuel Johnson as a moral authority hovering near the literary tradition influencing Austen's heroines.
The author cites Johnson's essay as a source of a warning against the dangers of imagination, noting that Austen was familiar with such Johnsonian pronouncements.
The author visualizes Dr. Johnson's hypothetical reaction to modern distractions like MTV Rap.
The author includes Johnson's collected works in the Canon.
The author quotes Dr. Johnson's personal reaction to Cordelia's death in King Lear, highlighting the scene's emotional impact.
The author references Johnson's critical writing on Milton as a precursor to Hazlitt's views.
The author draws a comparison between Beckett and Dr. Samuel Johnson regarding their perspectives on mortality.
The author references Johnson (and later Woolf) as the originator of the concept of the 'Common Reader'.

Intentia autorului a fost de a reconstitui trecutul nu ca durata consumata, ci ca exercitiu de percepere afectiva a consistentei unei etape. Pornit "in cautarea propriei existente", Proust recurge la procedeul mem...

raw.author: William Shakespeare
contexts: Dante is the largest instance of the first possibility, and Shakespeare, the overwhelming example of the second.

Dante’s Divine Comedy, according to Stefan George, was “the book and school of the ages,” though that was more true for poets than for anyone else and is properly assigned to Shakespeare’s plays, as will be shown throughout this book.
Shakespeare’s politics, insofar as we can pin them down, do not appear to be very different from those of his Coriolanus
Education founded upon the Iliad, the Bible, Plato, and Shakespeare remains, in some strained form, our ideal
Shakespeare’s own politics may or may not be those of Coriolanus, just as Shakespeare’s anxieties may or may not be those of Hamlet or of Lear.
Most simply, the Canon is Plato and Shakespeare; it is the image of the individual thinking, whether it be Socrates thinking through his own dying, or Hamlet contemplating that undiscovered country.
Milton rather possessively refers to his forerunner as “my Shakespeare,”
The real Stratfordian wrote thirty-eight plays in twenty-four years and then went home to die.
the era of Shakespeare is also the era of Spain.
The influence of Shakespeare on our Chaotic Age remains persuasive, particularly on Joyce and Beckett.
Shakespeare can as truly be seen as having invented the emotive and cognitive irony of ambivalence that governs Freud.
Universality is the authentic aspect of only a handful of Western writers: Shakespeare, Dante, Cervantes, perhaps Tolstoy.
Shakespeare, with Don Quixote, continues to center the Canon for more general readers.
Chaucer and Shakespeare bestow upon us: characters who change
Shakespeare was at once the source of Milton’s authentic if hidden poetic anxiety and, paradoxically, the engenderer of Milton’s canonicity.
Shakespeare unfolds Iago and Macbeth before us
Johnson on Shakespeare is never subtler than in his comment on the Duke’s astonishing “Be absolute for death” speech in act 3, scene 1 of Measure for Measure

E. R. Curtius’s Goethe is the perfecter and final representative of the literary culture that goes from Homer through Virgil to Dante and that achieved later sublimity in Shakespeare, Cervantes, Milton, and Racine.

Shakespeare, whom Goethe genially (and realistically) set above himself, is not quite as dominant an influence upon Part Two as he is upon Part One, which doubtless helps to account for the flood of classical characters, stories, and forms that surges through Part Two.
Goethe’s most profound debt to Shakespeare was the pragmatic realization that apotheosis can be dramatically persuasive.
Faust, Part One is a continuous parody of Shakespeare, with touches of Calderón and Milton added on.
Wordsworth in any case is a beginning, though like all great writers he was haunted by heroic precursors, Milton and Shakespeare beyond all others.
Perhaps Lear dies blasted by the mad hope that Cordelia lives, rather than by realistic despair that she is dead; but Shakespeare seems content to leave the matter equivocal.
because as a writer he was no more a male phenomenon than was Shakespeare, or Henry James.
with her hidden Shakespearean substitution.
and her underground affiliations are surprisingly Shakespearean.
a Shakespearean condition akin to what we might feel at the end of Hamlet’s death scene.
No other novel in English invents so much, though perhaps more in the mode of Ben Jonson than of Shakespeare.

If the question pertains to the beliefs in themselves, the answer would be positive in terms of the past, when there were so many Tolstoyans, but not now, when he must be read in the company of Homer, the Yah wist, Dante, and Shakespeare, as perhaps the only writer since the Renaissance who can challenge them.

Yet What Is Art? (1896)—his fierce denunciation of Greek tragedy, Dante, Michelangelo, Shakespeare, and Beethoven—is contravened by the astonishing Hadji Murad, the short novel he wrote between 1896 and 1904 but left unpublished when he died.
the hero is a Shakespearean version of Tolstoy in an ironic triumph of the dramatist over the writer who most maligned him.

Tolstoy has learned from Shakespeare (though he would have denied it) the art of juxtaposing highly diverse scenes in order to achieve more complex continuities than a simpler progression could provide.
Tolstoy absurdly attacked Shakespeare for being unable to endow his characters with individuality of language
Only Falstaff pleased him, and Lear in particular drove him wild with disdain.
His strongest character, Anna Karenina, has profound strains of Shakespeare in her, for which Tolstoy, who loves her, will not forgive her.
Since it is not hyperbolical to observe that Tolstoy actually hated Shakespeare, it is only just to add that he also feared him.
Hadji Murad is the grandest exception in late Tolstoy, for here the old shaman rivals Shakespeare.
Shakespeare’s extraordinary faculty for endowing even the most minor characters with exuberant being, for ramming them with life, is slyly absorbed by Tolstoy.
The catalog seems endless, as in a major Shakespearean play.
whom we come to know as we know Shakespeare’s great warriors: Othello, Antony, Coriolanus, or the bastard Faulconbridge in King John.
For once, like Shakespeare, Tolstoy speaks through a voice not at all his own and enacts the great role of Hadji Murad, the natural man as epic hero.
He is a Shakespearean protagonist whose deepest ethos is the capacity for inner change
Shakespeare upset Wittgenstein, who apparently feared the playwright of Hamlet and King Lear almost as much as Tolstoy did.

More than any other writer since Shakespeare, Tolstoy had the gift of representing the struggle for power in a warring world, and Hadji Murad is worthy of comparison to Antony in Antony and Cleopatra or to Conrad’s Nostromo.
Shakespearean in its characterization
Hedda’s true precursors were Shakespeare’s Iago and Edmund
That would be as uninteresting as saying her precursors Iago and Edmund are wicked fellows.
Doubtless Ibsen thought of Shakespeare’s hero-villains, Macbeth included, as being trolls; but that is not a very Shakespearean myth.
In Iago and Edmund, as in Hedda, there is a playfulness gone rancid, and insofar as the sublime Falstaff yields to a certain rancidity, a trollishness appears in him also.
Ibsen, like Cervantes and Shakespeare, is not interested in the Fall of Man.
For many years I have taught that Freud is essentially prosified Shakespeare: Freud’s vision of human psychology is derived, not altogether unconsciously, from his reading of the plays.
Shakespeare was the greatest of writers.
Shakespeare is the inventor of psychoanalysis; Freud, its codifier.
But no one who has read Shakespeare deeply, and who has attended Shakespeare properly directed and adequately acted, would consider Joyce the fulfillment of which Shakespeare was the forerunner.
“I should hesitate between Dante and Shakespeare, but not for long. The Englishman is richer and would get my vote.”

Joyce, a superb reader of Shakespeare, as well as a powerful misreader, builds through the Macbeth allusions to suggest that the Joycean, Shakespearean, Earwickian imagination is the killer, just as Macbeth’s extraordinary and proleptic strength of imagination has a murderousness all its own, which it imposes upon the rest of the play.
The earliest Shakespearean allusion in the Wake is to Macbeth, just as the final one is to King Lear.
“Duncan is in his grave; / After life’s fitful fever he sleeps well.”

Hodgart demonstrates that the Macbeth act 5, scene 5 soliloquy, the famous “Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow,” is echoed almost entire, as is Hamlet’s “To be or not to be” monologue, but each is scattered and strung out through the text of the Wake, an act of dispersal that is both useful to Joyce’s purposes and something of a revenge on the prevalence of Shapesphere!
not just Shakespeare but all writers were at once everyone and no one, a single, living labyrinth of literature.
In comparison to these family warriors, Homer and Shakespeare are ambiguously portrayed by Borges.
The masters of the will to live include Falstaff and Macbeth, or rather Falstaff as master and Macbeth as victim.
Hamlet, who necessarily haunted Beckett despite his professed preference for Racine, is master and victim, and as such pervades Beckett’s canonical drama, Endgame.
Beckett, like Joyce, presupposes a reader who knows Dante and Shakespeare, Flaubert and Yeats,
the Beckett of the dramas will survive as long as Shakespeare and Molière, Racine and Ibsen,
Endgame moves out from a Shakespearean paradigm that grafts elements of Lear, The Tempest, Richard III, and Macbeth onto Hamlet
behind them are the shadows of Shakespeare’s fools, culminating in the Feste of Twelfth Night.
Hamlet, The Tempest, and King Lear are all revised in Endgame
Shakespeare remains scripture

The author again identifies Shakespeare as a core canonical figure, exemplified by the introspective character Hamlet.
The author notes Milton's personal identification with Shakespeare as a source of influence and legacy.
The author discusses Shakespeare's life and prolific output as a playwright.
The author references Shakespeare in the context of a historical era, citing Ortega and Madariaga's conclusion.
The author states Shakespeare's influence persists in the modern Chaotic Age, specifically on Joyce and Beckett.
The author credits Shakespeare with inventing a form of irony that underlies Freud's work.
The author identifies Shakespeare as one of the few Western writers who possesses authentic universality.
The author asserts that Shakespeare, alongside Cervantes's Don Quixote, centers the Canon for general readers.

The author describes Shakespeare as a central, anxiety-inducing influence on Milton's work and canonical standing.
The author references Shakespeare as the creator of the characters Iago and Macbeth, contrasting his dramatic method with Milton's.
The author discusses Johnson's critical analysis of Shakespeare's play 'Measure for Measure'.
The author cites Curtius's view that Goethe is the culmination of a literary tradition that includes Shakespeare.
The author discusses Shakespeare's influence on Goethe's 'Faust', noting Goethe's acknowledgment of Shakespeare's superiority.
The author notes Goethe's artistic debt to Shakespeare regarding the dramatic use of apotheosis.
The author describes Goethe's Faust as a sustained parody of Shakespeare's works.
The author mentions Shakespeare as a heroic precursor who haunted Wordsworth.
The author references Shakespeare's ideas about hope and despair in King Lear as an imperfect analogue to Wordsworth's theme.
The author argues that Whitman's significance transcends gender, comparing him in this regard to Shakespeare.
The author references Shakespeare as an underlying influence on Dickinson's poetic technique of substitution.
The author cites Shakespeare as a source of surprising underground affiliations in Dickinson's work.
The author references Shakespeare to describe a state of bleak exultation, comparing it to the emotional impact at the end of Hamlet.
The author contrasts the inventiveness of Bleak House with the creative mode of Shakespeare.
The author places Tolstoy in the canonical company of Shakespeare, among others.
The author notes that Tolstoy's treatise 'What Is Art?' denounced Shakespeare, among others.
The author describes Tolstoy's protagonist as a Shakespearean version of Tolstoy himself, referencing Shakespeare's dramatic influence.
The author claims Tolstoy learned narrative techniques from Shakespeare, specifically the art of scene juxtaposition.
The author notes Tolstoy's criticism of Shakespeare regarding character language, referencing Shakespeare's dramatic style.
The author mentions Tolstoy's mixed reactions to Shakespeare's characters Falstaff and King Lear.
The author suggests Tolstoy's character Anna Karenina contains Shakespearean elements, which Tolstoy resented.
The author asserts Tolstoy harbored both hatred and fear towards Shakespeare as a literary figure.
The author states that in 'Hadji Murad', Tolstoy achieves a level of artistry that rivals Shakespeare.
The author claims Tolstoy absorbed Shakespeare's technique of vividly animating even minor characters.
The author compares the extensive character list in 'Hadji Murad' to that of a major Shakespearean play.
The author compares the depth of understanding of Hadji Murad to that of Shakespeare's warrior characters like Othello and Antony.
The author notes that Tolstoy, like Shakespeare, adopts a voice distinct from his own to portray his protagonist.
The author invokes Shakespeare as a benchmark for tragic protagonists.
The author discusses Wittgenstein's and Tolstoy's troubled relationship with Shakespeare's works.
The author compares Tolstoy's character Hadji Murad to Shakespeare's Antony, noting Tolstoy's gift for representing power struggles akin to Shakespeare's.
The author compares Tolstoy's character portrayal to Shakespeare's methods.
The author argues that Ibsen's character Hedda Gabler is derived from Shakespeare's villains Iago and Edmund.
The author references Shakespeare's characters Iago and Edmund as precursors to Hedda Gabler, dismissing simplistic moral judgments of them as 'wicked fellows'.
The author speculates that Ibsen viewed Shakespeare's hero-villains like Macbeth as trolls, while noting this interpretation isn't inherently Shakespearean.
The author draws a parallel between the rancid playfulness in Shakespeare's Iago, Edmund, and Falstaff and the trollishness in Ibsen's Hedda Gabler.
The author mentions Shakespeare as an author who, like Ibsen, does not focus on the theme of the Fall of Man.
The author argues that Freud's psychological theories are fundamentally derived from his reading of Shakespeare's plays.
The author states that Freud recognized Shakespeare as the greatest writer.
The author credits Shakespeare as the inventor of psychoanalysis, positioning him as a precursor to Freud.
The author argues that Joyce, despite his ambition, is not the fulfillment of a tradition for which Shakespeare was the forerunner.

raw.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
contexts: the motive for metaphor that Nietzsche once defined as the desire to be different, the desire to be elsewhere.
Nietzsche would have called it pain; but they would have been thinking of the same experience upon the heights.
Hayden White long ago exposed Foucault’s great flaw as being a blindness toward his own metaphors, an ironic weakness in a professed disciple of Nietzsche.
Aesthetic value rises out of memory, and so (as Nietzsche saw) out of pain, the pain of surrendering easier pleasures in favor of much more difficult ones.
Yet only strength can join itself to strength, as Nietzsche perpetually testified.
Refreshingly, he is not Nietzsche or King Lear, and he declined to go mad, though he had the imagination of madness, as of everything else.
Interpreting Hamlet becomes as difficult as interpreting such aphorists as Emerson, Nietzsche, and Kierkegaard.

So pungent are the Pardoner’s presence and his narration that the marginal becomes central in Chaucer, inaugurating what Nietzsche was to call “the uncanniest guest,” the representation of European nihilism.
Nietzsche taught us a poetics of pain; only the painful, he brilliantly insisted, could truly be memorable.

"Error about life is necessary for life," a crucial Nietzschean insight, is part of Nietzsche’s large (and acknowledged) debt to Goethe, whose idea of poetry centered upon a complex awareness that poetry essentially was trope, and that trope was a kind of creative error.
Perhaps that is why Goethe appealed so immensely to the perspectivizing Nietzsche

raw.author: Michel de Montaigne
contexts: Since that voyage goes past harbors as infinite as Dante, Chaucer, Montaigne, Shakespeare, and Tolstoy, all of whom amply compensate a lifetime’s rereadings
Again, there are character traits that Shakespeare shares with Montaigne, but Montaigne’s life of creative retirement was punctuated by high politics and civil war.
It is not a philosophy; it is no didactic purpose; it is not even a being stirred by the uncertainty of human existence or by the power of destiny, as in the case of Montaigne and Shakespeare.
Perhaps one could designate a composite author, Montaigne-Molière, for the greatest of essayists was the spiritual father of Shakespeare’s only rival as a comic dramatist.
He has a surprising affinity to Shakespeare, in which a mutual relation to Montaigne may play a part.
Both characters stem from aspects of Montaigne, and both justify Nietzsche’s savage, permanently disturbing apothegm
Nietzsche’s vehement insight applies to speaking, not to writing, so it is antithetical to the art of Montaigne the essayist.
Montaigne’s triumph was to fuse himself and his book in an overt act that has to be called originality
Like every major canonical author, Montaigne startles the common reader at each fresh encounter
He can be interpreted as skeptic, humanist, Catholic, Stoic, even Epicurean, very nearly what you will.

His scope and capaciousness sometimes approach Shakespearean dimensions, and one way to consider him, though he knew nothing of Shakespeare while Shakespeare knew something of him, is as the largest-scale of all Shakespearean characters, huger than Hamlet as a questing self.
Montaigne changes as he rereads and revises his own book; more perhaps than in any other instance, the book is the man is the book.
Montaigne, in his final phase, associated his stance regarding life with that of the common people; but Molière, like Shakespeare, rarely gives us an insight into his own deepest sympathies.
I resort to Montaigne against the critics, if we are to save Alceste from them.
Montaigne taught Molière the pragmatic elusiveness of truth—a superb lesson for an actor to learn, and one that would have benefited Alceste if he could have borne it, but he could not.
Montaigne and Molière alike avoid the tragic vision that Lucien Goldmann ascribed to Pascal and Racine in The Hidden God.

The movement from humanism to celebration of the common life, which Frame traced in Montaigne, was thoroughly absorbed by Molière, whose ideal audience would have been the honest men with whom Montaigne had replaced the humanistic ideal.
Montaigne’s originality had been the self-portrait, hardly the stuff from which a comic playwright could fashion his work.
I surmise that Molière took Montaigne’s hint but inverted the self-portraiture or turned it inside out.
Alceste, forceful and admirable as I find him to be, is the direct consequence of not acting upon Montaigne’s admonition that concludes “Of Experience.”
as we more naturally expect to find in the skeptical Montaigne and in Freud, for whom religion was an illusion.
Emerson is a wisdom writer, like Nietzsche, Kierkegaard, Freud, and his precursor, Montaigne.
indeed it is the mind of our age, as Montaigne was the mind of Shakespeare’s.
Search is wisdom literature, even as Montaigne, Dr. Johnson, Emerson, and Freud are finally authors who touch a border between meditation and contemplation.

from Hesiod’s contest with Homer down to the agon between Dickinson and Elizabeth Bishop.

be it in Homer, Dante, or Tolstoy.

raw.author: Miguel de Unamuno
contexts: Against that claim I set the most poignant and Quixotic of all critical agonists, the Basque man of letters Miguel de Unamuno, whose “tragic sense of life” was founded upon his intimate relationship with Cervantes’ masterpiece, which for Unamuno replaced the Bible as the authentic Spanish Scripture.
Unamuno, as sublimely crazy as his lord, Don Quixote, delightfully comments, “All of which should teach us to liberate galley slaves precisely because they will not be grateful to us for it.”
Unamuno is again the useful Cervantine critic here
Unamuno says of Quixote that he went out to seek his true fatherland and found it in exile.
Unamuno’s reaction seems to me the best one on the Quixotic loss of his wits: “He lost them for our sake, for our benefit, so as to leave us an eternal example of spiritual generosity.”

Don Quixote, of course, imposes moral constraints upon his sexual desires to such an extent that he might as well be a priest, which according to Unamuno he truly was: a priest of the true Spanish church, the Quixotic.
The tragic sense of life, discovered by Unamuno in Don Quixote, is also the faith of Moby-Dick.
The Don’s motive, according to Unamuno, is eternal fame, interpreted as “an expansion of the personality in space and time.”

As I do, Unamuno took most seriously the Don’s sublimated desire for Aldonza Lorenzo and his subsequent Beatrice-like exaltation of her as the angelic if unfortunately enchanted Dulcinea, which allows us to see the knight in something close to his full complexity.
Unamuno’s Quixote is a paradoxical agonist, the ancestor of the diminished questers who wander through our chaos in Kafka and Beckett.

contexts: There is no strangeness and no originality in such resentment; even if there were, they would not suffice to create heirs of the Yah wist and Homer, Dante and Shakespeare, Cervantes and Joyce.
The true use of Shakespeare or of Cervantes, of Homer or of Dante, of Chaucer or of Rabelais, is to augment one’s own growing inner self.
Shakespeare has his personal affinities with the subdued Cervantes, but Cervantes unwillingly led a life of extravagant action and catastrophic misfortune.
These were examples of Christian and moral art, though “good universal art” was also ac ceptable in a curious secondary grouping that included Cervantes and Molière.
What is the Shakespearean difference that demands Dante, Cervantes, Tolstoy, and only a few others as aesthetic companions?
the major figures of the Spanish Golden Age—Cervantes, Lope de Vega, Calderón, Tirso de Molina, Rojas, Góngora—brought to Hispanic literature a baroque exuberance
many critics have felt the affinities between Cervantes and Shakespeare
Universality is the authentic aspect of only a handful of Western writers: Shakespeare, Dante, Cervantes, perhaps Tolstoy.
With Don Quixote, Sancho Panza, and Panurge they make up a company or family devoted to the order of play, as opposed to the order of society or of the organized spirit.

E. R. Curtius’s Goethe is the perfecter and final representative of the literary culture that goes from Homer through Virgil to Dante and that achieved later sublimity in Shakespeare, Cervantes, Milton, and Racine.
Shakespeare and Dante, Goethe, Cervantes, and Tolstoy destroy all genre distinctions by and in their work.

The Don and Cervantes no one need speculate upon, for Cervantes memorably ends his epic romance with an overt declaration: “For me alone Don Quixote was born, and I for him. He knew how to act, and I knew how to write. We two alone are as one.”
Ibsen, like Cervantes and Shakespeare, is not interested in the Fall of Man.
There is a great love for them in Borges, as there is also a passion for Dante, Cervantes, Whitman, Kafka, and others; but there is a great ambivalence as well.
He is a character like Don Quixote or Hamlet, but someone no less complex and possibly more lovable than either of them.

raw.title: Faust
raw.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
contexts: His wisdom transmutes endlessly in all our sages, from Goethe to Freud, even though Shakespeare declined to step forward as a sage.
For Freud, as for Goethe, the works of Shakespeare were the secular center of culture, the hope for a rational glory in mankind still to come.

The German tragedies are not rated even that high: Goethe, despite his early Shakespeareanism, falls away from characterization into an exaltation of passion, and Schiller is rejected for having substituted violence for reality.
Lucretius, Dante, and Goethe

Of all post-Shakespearean writers it is Milton, rather than Goethe or Tolstoy or Ibsen, who best exploited the Shakespearean representation of character and its changes, even while working furiously to ward off the Shakespearean shadow.
Goethe’s Faust, Part Two: The Countercanonical Poem
When he wrote of Mephistopheles, Goethe was a true poet, and of the Devil’s party while knowing it, because Goethe seems to have known everything.
Faust, Part Two is the central work of European Romanticism
As soon as Goethe’s monsters have begun to speak, even their ill-temper is no more awesome than the verbal bad manners of the fantastics in Through the Looking Glass.
Thomas Mann, in an odd essay on “Goethe and Tolstoy,” confirms this point
his conversion of Shakespearean tragedy and Goethean fantasy into a new kind of Northern tragicomedy

He is the democratic heir of the aristocratic Goethe, and though he could not equal Faust, Part Two as a dramatic poem, he possessed the secret that Goethe never learned, how to revive poetic drama in the post-Enlightenment.
Far more than Goethe’s Faust (whom Ibsen greatly admired)
Peer, we suddenly see, is the link between Goethe’s Faust and Joyce’s Poldy Bloom.
Peer’s impulse is a parody of Faust’s in Part Two of Goethe’s poem, which haunts Ibsen’s acts 4 and 5.
The Strange Passenger and the Button-Molder are thwarted by the same Byronic and Goethean enigma.
Ibsen’s debt to Goethe here was shrewdly worked out in 1942, by A. E. Zucker, who rightly compared the Button-Molder’s tone to that of Mephistopheles.
Freud loved Shakespeare as he loved Goethe and Milton.
It does not differ in kind, only in degree, from Shakespeare’s influence upon Goethe, Ibsen, Joyce, and so many others who are the subject of this book.

According to the view which was originated by Goethe and is still the prevailing one today, Hamlet represents the type of man whose power of direct action is paralysed by an excessive development of his intellect.
I turn again to the Nietzschean refinement of Goethe’s view, which is that Hamlet thinks not too much but much too well
Behind all of them is Goethe in his role as wisdom writer, with the Aristophanic Heine adding a note of Jewish skepticism, which found its way into Kafka.
Kafka, perhaps by way of Goethe’s influence, inherits the German sense of Hamlet as the hero too intricate and sensitive to prevail in a botched cosmos.

raw.author: Benjamin Bennett
contexts: Benjamin Bennett finds the poem’s project to be no less than “the regeneration of language,” which I might reduce to “an attempt to regenerate German as Shakespeare regenerated English.”
Bennett considers the weird nongenre of Faust an “antipoetic” that seeks to purge irony from poetic language and restore a kind of visionary pathos.
With a grand (and deliberate) critical irrealism, Bennett proclaims that the size of Faust is “infinite in the sense of being as large as one pleases.”
Bennett very usefully reminds us that the peculiar art of Faust is that the poem systematically cancels out all of the perspectives from which we might wish to view it.
Benjamin Bennett demonstrates that the four remaining acts of Part Two all conclude with progressively subtler suggestions of masturbatory climaxes.
commentaries: The author summarizes Bennett's critical view that Faust aims at the regeneration of language, comparing its ambition to Shakespeare's transformation of English.
The author reports Bennett's characterization of Faust as an 'antipoetic' genre that attempts to eliminate irony and recover visionary emotion.

The author cites Bennett's insight that Faust's artistic method involves the systematic negation of all interpretative perspectives.
The author cites Benjamin Bennett's scholarly analysis regarding the structure of climaxes in Faust, Part Two.

goodreads_match.description: The narrative drive of Stowe's classic novel is often overlooked in the heat of the controversies surrounding its anti-slavery sentiments. Stowe's puritanical religious beliefs show up in the novel's final, overarching theme--the exploration of the nature of Christianity and how Christian theology is fundamentally incompatible with slavery.

contexts: Of all post-Shakespearean writers it is Milton, rather than Goethe or Tolstoy or Ibsen, who best exploited the Shakespearean representation of character and its changes, even while working furiously to ward off the Shakespearean shadow.

the Beckett of the dramas will survive as long as Shakespeare and Molière, Racine and Ibsen,
is finally about as cheerful as late Ibsen in its implications.
Joyce’s one play, Exiles, is an exercise in Ibsenism
a challenge not taken up by Ibsen, though it flickers on and off in Emperor Julian in Emperor and Galilean.

raw.author: Virgil
contexts: Dante, as I only begin to see, creatively corrected Virgil
Dante affects the way we read Virgil, and Shakespeare can severely alter our approach to Milton.

Augustine and Aquinas have the same relation to Dante’s theology that Virgil and Cavalcanti have to Dante’s poetry: all forerunners are dwarfed by the poet-theologian, the prophet Dante, who is the author of the final testament, the Comedy.
Virgil’s Ulysses will become Dante’s, but so transmuted as to make Virgil’s rather evasive portrait tend to fade away.
Virgil’s Aeneas is something of a prig, and that is what many of his scholars turn Dante into, or would if they could.
As much as any other poet except Shakespeare, Dante has no poetic father, even though he asserts that Virgil occupies such a place.
Dante’s designated precursor was Virgil, and if there is a parallel to Beatrice in the Aeneid, it has to be Venus.
What makes Paradise Lost unique is its startling blend of Shakespearean tragedy, Virgilian epic, and Biblical prophecy.

E. R. Curtius’s Goethe is the perfecter and final representative of the literary culture that goes from Homer through Virgil to Dante and that achieved later sublimity in Shakespeare, Cervantes, Milton, and Racine.

In the same way, the crucial early writer in the history of the entire Western literary Canon is not one of the greatest poets—Homer, Dante, Chaucer, and Shakespeare—but Virgil, the great link between Hellenistic poetry (Callimachus) and the European epic tradition (Dante, Tasso, Spenser, Milton).
Virgil The Aeneid, translated by Robert Fitzgerald Eclogues and Georgics, translated by John Dryden
commentaries: The author notes Dante's creative correction of Virgil's work.

raw.title: Suspiria de Profundis
raw.author: Thomas De Quincey
contexts: Borges’ procedures and obsessions are very near those of the author of Confessions of an English Opium-Eater and the unfinished Suspiria de Profundis.
commentaries: The author states that Borges's methods and themes are closely aligned with those of De Quincey, specifically referencing his works 'Confessions of an English Opium-Eater' and 'Suspiria de Profundis'.

goodreads_match.title: Suspiria de Profundis
goodreads_match.description: A collection of dream visions and autobiographical essays by Thomas De Quincey, published as a sequel to 'Confessions of an English Opium-Eater'. It contains his famous essay 'Levana and Our Ladies of Sorrow'.

raw.title: James Joyce and the Making of “Ulysses”
raw.author: Frank Budgen
contexts: Frank Budgen’s James Joyce and the Making of “Ulysses” (1934), still the best guide to the book because it has so much of the personal Joyce in it, tells us that “Shakespeare the man, the lord of language, the creator of persons, occupied [Joyce] more than Shakespeare the maker of plays.”
commentaries: The author cites Budgen's book as the best guide to Joyce's 'Ulysses' and quotes its insight about Joyce's focus on Shakespeare the man.

goodreads_match.title: James Joyce and the Making of 'Ulysses'
goodreads_match.description: A memoir and critical study by Frank Budgen, a friend and contemporary of James Joyce, detailing Joyce's creative process and personal insights during the writing of 'Ulysses'.

raw.author: Saint Jerome
contexts: A scale of perfection that sets widowhood over marriage, as Saint Jerome did, makes no sense to her;
commentaries: The author references Saint Jerome's teachings on widowhood and marriage as a point of ideological contrast for the Wife of Bath.

raw.title: European Literature and the Latin Middle Ages
raw.author: Ernst Robert Curtius
contexts: Curtius in his masterwork, European Literature and the Latin Middle Ages (1948; 1953 in English), brings together two splendid statements on trope by Goethe.
commentaries: The author references Curtius's scholarly work as a source for Goethe's statements on literary tropes.

goodreads_match.title: European Literature and the Latin Middle Ages
goodreads_match.description: A foundational work of medieval literary scholarship tracing the continuity of literary forms and topoi from antiquity through the Middle Ages to the modern era.

raw.title: Analysis Terminable and Interminable
raw.author: Sigmund Freud
contexts: My reference was clearly to Freud’s plangent and eloquent summa, “Analysis Terminable and Interminable,” the lament of the founder of psychoanalysis that his patients would not accept their cure from him.
commentaries: The author references Freud's work to draw an analogy with Dante's pride, noting that Dante, like Freud's patients, would only accept a cure from his own creation.

goodreads_match.title: Analysis Terminable and Interminable
goodreads_match.description: A major late essay by Sigmund Freud, originally published in German as 'Die endliche und die unendliche Analyse', in which he reflects on the limits and challenges of psychoanalytic treatment.

raw.title: Towards Historical Rhetorics
raw.author: Peter de Bolla
contexts: This point has been well expressed by Peter de Bolla in his book Towards Historical Rhetorics: the Freudian family romance as a description of influence represents an extremely weak reading.
commentaries: The author cites de Bolla's book to support a critique of Freudian interpretations of literary influence.

goodreads_match.title: Towards Historical Rhetorics
goodreads_match.description: A scholarly work examining rhetorical theory and its historical development, applying critical theory to the study of rhetoric.

raw.author: Saint Paul
contexts: the fiercest of parodies of Saint Paul in Corinthians (“O death, where is thy sting? O grave, where is thy victory?”)
commentaries: The author notes that Joyce's text parodies a passage from Saint Paul's First Epistle to the Corinthians.

raw.title: The Grimness of the Truth
raw.author: Laura Quinney
contexts: A fine study by Laura Quinney, The Grimness of the Truth, applies Wittgenstein’s dialectical attitude toward the tragic sense of life to both Dr. Johnson and Shelley.
commentaries: The author cites Quinney's book as a study applying Wittgenstein's ideas to other literary figures.

goodreads_match.title: The Grimness of the Truth
goodreads_match.description: A scholarly work applying Wittgenstein's philosophy to the tragic sense of life in Samuel Johnson and Percy Bysshe Shelley.

raw.title: The Swan at the Well: Shakespeare Reading Chaucer
raw.author: Talbot Donaldson
contexts: Talbot Donaldson in The Swan at the Well: Shakespeare Reading Chaucer captures the most striking parallel between these endless soliloquists and monologists
commentaries: The author cites Donaldson's book to support the analysis of parallels between Shakespeare's and Chaucer's characters, specifically regarding their absorption in play.

goodreads_match.title: The Swan at the Well: Shakespeare Reading Chaucer
goodreads_match.description: A scholarly work examining Shakespeare's engagement with and adaptation of Chaucer's works, focusing on literary parallels and influences.
